title: How To Treat and Prevent Dry Knuckles

steps.title: Get an unscented cream or ointment to moisturize your knuckles.
steps.content: Get an unscented cream or ointment to moisturize your knuckles. The simplest way to treat dry knuckles is with a good moisturizer. Get a fragrance-free type, since fragrances can dry out your skin more. Ointments and creams are better than lotion because they’re thicker and lock in more moisture. Pick up one of these products from any pharmacy. Particularly good moisturizer brands include Eucerin and Cetaphil. You could also use oils like baby oil. These tend to stay on your skin longer and lock in more moisture than creams. Petroleum jelly works as a good moisturizer, but you might find this a little too greasy or slippery. [1] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Even something as simple as coconut oil can help restore moisture to your skin. [2] X Expert Source Mohiba Tareen, MD FAAD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 26 March 2020.

steps.title: Massage the moisturizer into the skin around your knuckles.
steps.content: Massage the moisturizer into the skin around your knuckles. Letting the moisturizer sit on the surface of your skin isn’t quite enough to treat very dry skin. Instead, massage it into your skin every time you use it so it really soaks in. [3] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Remember to get between your fingers as well. If you have dry knuckles, then the skin between your fingers is probably dry too. You can use the moisturizer as often as you need throughout the day to heal cracks and dryness. [4] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply moisturizer right after bathing or washing your hands.
steps.content: Apply moisturizer right after bathing or washing your hands. Water is particularly dehydrating and strips away oils from your skin. Any time you wash your hands, bathe, or take a shower, apply moisturizer within 3 minutes. This locks in moisture before it evaporates and prevents your hands from drying out. [5] X Research source Try to get a small travel-size moisturizer so you can have it with you when you wash your hands away from home. Moisturizing your skin will help keep protect the barrier that protects you from inflammation, irritation, and allergens. [6] X Expert Source Mohiba Tareen, MD FAAD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 26 March 2020.

steps.title: Sleep with moisturizer on to hydrate your skin overnight.
steps.content: Sleep with moisturizer on to hydrate your skin overnight. If your knuckles are very dry and cracked, then you might need a bit more than occasional moisturizing. Right before bed, rub a thick layer of moisturizer onto your hands, especially the dry spots. Then put on a pair of cotton gloves so the moisturizer doesn’t rub off overnight. This way, the moisturizer can soak in all night. This is a good way to use petroleum jelly, since it can be a little too greasy to use during the day. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Run a humidifier in your home to hydrate your skin.
steps.content: Run a humidifier in your home to hydrate your skin. Dry air could also be causing your dry skin, especially during the winter when you have the heat on. Try running a humidifier in your home to moisten the air and prevent your skin from drying out more. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Open up your humidifier regularly to check if the filter is dirty. If it is, clean it by rinsing it with water and letting it dry.

steps.title: Wash your hands with mild, fragrance-free soap.
steps.content: Wash your hands with mild, fragrance-free soap. Fragrances and scents are irritating and could dry your skin out more. Choose only mild, fragrance-free soaps designed for sensitive skin to protect your hands from further damage. Dial, Cetaphil, Toms, and Dove all make soaps designed for sensitive skin. Try seeing what these brands have to offer if you don't know where to start. Usually soaps labeled “hypoallergenic” are free of any ingredients that could irritate or dry your skin. Also avoid piling on so much soap that your hands are covered in a thick lather. This strips away natural oils. Hot water is irritating as well, so keep it warm instead.

steps.title: Apply moisturizing hand sanitizer to combat dryness.
steps.content: Apply moisturizing hand sanitizer to combat dryness. Alcohol-based hand sanitizers are irritating and strip away oils from your skin. If you regularly use hand sanitizer, get a moisturizing type instead. These are less harsh on your hands and can prevent dryness. Purell makes a hand sanitizer with aloe vera and vitamin E for moisturizer. The drawback is that moisturizing hand sanitizer isn’t as effective in killing viruses, so keep that in mind if you use it.

steps.title: Wear gloves while you’re outside in the cold.
steps.content: Wear gloves while you’re outside in the cold. Cold, windy weather is one of the main causes of dry knuckles. If you’re going outside in cold weather, protect your hands with gloves. This can treat dry skin or prevent it altogether. [9] X Trustworthy Source Seattle Children's Hospital Health information provided by Seattle Children's hospital. Go to source Try to wear gentle, natural fabrics like cotton. These won’t irritate your skin. Rough fabrics like wool are irritating and might make your skin worse. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you live in a climate with very dry air, you may also want to use a humidifier inside of your home. [11] X Expert Source Mohiba Tareen, MD FAAD Board Certified Dermatologist Expert Interview. 26 March 2020.

steps.title: Protect your hands with rubber gloves while cleaning.
steps.content: Protect your hands with rubber gloves while cleaning. If you’re doing the dishes or cleaning around your home, the soap and water can dry out your skin quickly. Wear rubber cleaning gloves to protect your hands until you’re done. [12] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source It’s also a good idea to moisturize after cleaning or washing dishes to prevent more dryness.

steps.title: Limit your bath or shower time to 10 minutes.
steps.content: Limit your bath or shower time to 10 minutes. Hot water and soap strip oils from your skin, especially if you’re in for a long time. Keep your showers and baths short and get out after 10 minutes to prevent more dryness. [13] X Research source Try to bathe only once a day to avoid more dryness. It’s also helpful to keep the water warm instead of hot, since hot water is irritating. Remember to moisturize after bathing, no matter how long it was!

steps.title: Hold a cold compress on your skin if it itches.
steps.content: Hold a cold compress on your skin if it itches. Dry skin could be itchy or uncomfortable. If your knuckles are bothering you, then soothe the area with a cold pack. [14] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Wrap the compress in a towel and hold it against the itchy area for 10-15 minutes at a time. You could also use a bag of frozen vegetables as a makeshift cold compress. Never put a cold pack directly onto your skin without a towel or rag around it. This could damage your skin.

steps.title: Try hydrocortisone cream if the itching doesn’t stop.
steps.content: Try hydrocortisone cream if the itching doesn’t stop. Hydrocortisone fights inflammation, so it might do the trick if you still feel itchy. Get a cream with 1% hydrocortisone and apply it to the itchy areas to see if that helps. Hydrocortisone cream is available without a prescription from any pharmacy. [15] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Always read the instructions on the cream you use and don’t use it more than you’re supposed to. If you have any questions, ask the pharmacist on duty.

steps.title: See your doctor if your skin doesn’t get better.
steps.content: See your doctor if your skin doesn’t get better. If you’ve been treating your skin at home and it hasn’t gotten any better, then you might need a different treatment. Make an appointment with your doctor or dermatologist to get the problem checked out. The doctor can then advise you on the best next steps to take. [16] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source In rarer cases, dry knuckles can be from eczema or dermatitis. If your hands are also red, itchy, blistered, or painful, then see a dermatologist for an exam. [17] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source

steps.title: Apply prescription-strength cream to reduce inflammation if directed by your doctor.
steps.content: Apply prescription-strength cream to reduce inflammation if directed by your doctor. When you see a dermatologist, they'll probably prescribe you a strong cream or ointment to heal your skin. Follow your doctor's instructions to apply the cream correctly. This should help moisturize your skin. [18] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Dermatology Professional organization made of over 20,000 certified dermatologists Go to source Stronger hydrocortisone cream is a common treatment for dry and irritated skin. This is probably what your dermatologist will prescribe.
